Powers of an Element

For an element $a \in M$ of a monoid and an exponent $n \in \mathbb{N}$, the $n$th power of $a$, denoted $a^n$, is defined in the usual way. Note that $a^0 = e$, following the convention on empty products.
Normal Subgroup
A subgroup $H \subset G$ is called a normal subgroup of $G$ if $aH = Ha$ for all $a \in G$, i.e., if for each element $a \in G$ the associated left and right cosets of $H$ in $G$ coincide.
Integral Domain
A commutative ring R is called an integral domain if it is nonzero and does not admit nontrivial zero divisors.
Principal Ideal
For an element $a \in R$, the principal ideal generated by $a$ is $R a:=\{r a ; r \in R\}$. It is the smallest ideal in $R$ containing $a$.
Factorial ring/unique factorization domain

An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.
Field of Fractions

For an integral domain $R$, the field of fractions $Q(R)$ is the set of equivalence classes of pairs $(a, b)$ where $a, b \in R$ and $b \neq 0$, under the equivalence relation defined by $(a, b) \sim (a', b')$ if and only if $ab' = a'b$.
Torsion submodule
The torsion submodule T of an A-module M consists of all torsion elements of M. If T = 0, M is called torsion-free; if T = M, it is called a torsion module.
Algebra over a Ring

An algebra $B$ over a ring $A$ is defined as a ring homomorphism $A \longrightarrow B$. A homomorphism between two $A$-algebras $B$ and $C$ is a ring homomorphism $B \longrightarrow C$ that is compatible with the defining homomorphisms $A \longrightarrow B$ and $A \longrightarrow C$, ensuring the commutativity of the diagram involving these maps.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.
Noetherian ring

A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.
Disjoint Cycles
Two cycles $(x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$ and $(y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s})$ are called disjoint if the sets $\{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$ and $\{y_{1}, \ldots, y_{s}\}$ have no elements in common.
Domain
The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.
Inheritance_Analysis

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A factorial ring or unique factorization domain (UFD) is a specialization of an integral domain. By definition, a UFD is an integral domain that additionally satisfies the conditions of unique factorization into irreducible elements, which are prime. Thus, every UFD is an integral domain, but not every integral domain is a UFD.

The field of fractions is a concept that specifically applies to integral domains. The field of fractions of an integral domain R, denoted Q(R), is constructed using the elements of R, where R is an integral domain. Thus, the concept of a field of fractions is a specialization of the concept of an integral domain.
